## 2023 Assessment: Model Improvements {data-background-image="static/spc-slide-sidebar.png" data-background-size="5% 100%" data-background-position="left"}

::: {style="margin-left: 1.5%; margin-right: 1.5%; font-size: 0.6em; line-height: 1.3;"}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
### Major Changes from 2020

**Catch-conditioned model** [@day2023bet]:
- Reduced from 11,421 to 3,067 parameters
- More stable convergence

**sdmTMB CPUE standardization** [@hamer2023cpue]:
- Spatial-temporal modeling framework
- Replaced VAST approach

**Lorenzen natural mortality** [@lorenzen1996]:
- Size/age-dependent M scaling
- More realistic mortality patterns

**Internal growth estimation** [@farley2020growth]:
- Von Bertalanffy parameters estimated
- 1,004 otoliths incorporated
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Independent Review Integration

**Punt et al. (2023)** [@punt2023review]:
- Reviewed 2020 YFT assessment
- **SC19 decision**: Apply to BET where practical

**Key recommendations implemented**:
- Revised tagger effects modeling [@peatman2023tagger]
- Tag mixing period as grid axis
- Size composition reweighting methods
- Growth-M correlation handling

### Rigorous Convergence Process

**Extensive jittering** [@day2023bet]:
- Up to 60 runs per model to find global optimum
- Diagnostic model achieved positive definite Hessian
- 48 of 54 grid models converged
:::
:::

:::

::: {.notes}
- Stock status 2021: SB/SBF=0 = 34% (just below 40% LRP median), overfishing occurring (primarily purse seine FADs)
- Recruitment stable since 1960: ~120 million fish/year, no impairment evidence
- Data inputs: 70-year time series (1952-2021), 41 fisheries, ~67K BET tagged, longline CPUE indices
- 54-model grid: Tag mixing (1Q/2Q/3Q most influential), steepness (0.65/0.80/0.95), size comp weighting, age data weighting
- High parameter uncertainty: M/growth/recruitment correlations, sensitivity to starting values
- Key limitations: Limited age data, 9-region complexity, size comp vs tagging conflicts, tag mixing uncertainty
- SC19 evaluation: "More rigorous but model instability remains" → 14 research recommendations
:::

## 2023 Assessment: Results & Uncertainty {data-background-image="static/spc-slide-sidebar.png" data-background-size="5% 100%" data-background-position="left"}

::: {style="margin-left: 1.5%; margin-right: 1.5%; font-size: 0.6em; line-height: 1.3;"}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
### Stock Status (2021)

**SB/SB~F=0~ = 34%** [@day2023bet]:
- Just below LRP (40%)
- Median across 54-model grid

**Fishing mortality above F~MSY~**:
- Overfishing occurring
- Primarily from purse seine associated sets

**Recruitment stable** since 1960:
- ~120 million fish/year
- No evidence of recruitment impairment

### Data Inputs

**Time series**: 1952-2021 (70 years)

**Size compositions**: 41 fisheries

**Tagging**: ~67K BET (RTTP, PTTP, JPTP)

**CPUE**: Longline indices (9 regions)
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Structural Uncertainty Grid

**54 models** exploring [@day2023bet]:
- **Tag mixing**: 1Q, 2Q, 3Q (most influential)
- **Steepness**: 0.65, 0.80, 0.95
- **Size comp weighting**: 3 methods
- **Age data weighting**: 6 levels

### Remaining Challenges

**High parameter uncertainty**:
- Correlations between M, growth, recruitment
- Sensitivity to starting values

**Key data limitations**:
1. Limited age data (1,004 otoliths)
2. Spatial structure complexity (9 regions)
3. Size composition conflicts with tagging
4. Tag mixing period uncertain

**SC19 Evaluation** [@sc19outcomes]:

"More rigorous... but **model instability remains**"

**Result**: **14 research recommendations**
:::
:::

:::

::: {.notes}
- Data collection: Continue age/tagging (#1), develop CPUE indices (#2), account for effort creep (#3), review size comp representativeness (#11), investigate weight vs tagging inversion (#12)
- Model structure: Simulation study for 6-region (#4), identify correlated/sensitive parameters (#9), reduce starting condition sensitivity (#13)
- Biological parameters: Investigate unfished SSB increase in tropics (#5), yield-per-recruit analyses (#6), evaluate growth/mortality variability (#7), explore seasonal/regional growth (#10)
- Diagnostics: Additional biological sensitivities (#8), tag mixing diagnostics (#14)
- These 14 recommendations provide clear roadmap for 2026 assessment preparation
:::

::: {style="text-align: center; padding-top: 35%; color: white;"}
### 7 Key Problems Identified

- Each issue linked to specific SC19 recommendations
- Issues range from data quality to model structure to convergence challenges
:::

- Only 1,004 otoliths aged - insufficient for reliable internal growth estimation
- High parameter uncertainty affects biomass scaling and stock status
- No spatial/seasonal coverage for regional growth differences

## Issue #1: Age Data Quality {data-background-image="static/spc-slide-sidebar.png" data-background-size="5% 100%" data-background-position="left"}

::: {style="margin-left: 1.5%; margin-right: 1.5%; font-size: 0.6em; line-height: 1.3;"}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="52%"}
### Problem

- **Only 1,004 otoliths** aged — insufficient for internal growth estimation
- High parameter uncertainty, affects biomass scaling
- No spatial coverage for regional growth differences

### Impact

- Cannot reliably estimate von Bertalanffy parameters
- Growth-M correlation issues
- Limited ability to test spatial/seasonal variation

### SC19-#1, #7, #10

Continue age data collection; evaluate growth/mortality variability; explore regional traits

:::

::: {.column width="48%"}
![Sampling locations of fish aged [@day2023bet]](figures/prepaw/bet2023-fig-016.png){width=100%}
:::
:::

:::

::: {.notes}
- 9-region problems: 41 fisheries, 3,067 parameters, ~24-hour runtime, persistent convergence issues
- Hessian non-positive definite, high parameter correlations, jittering sensitivity
- Evidence for 6-region: Low tropical-temperate movement, high within-zone mixing, size composition clustering
- 6-region used successfully 2005-2011: Faster runtime, fewer parameters, better convergence
- SC19 recommendation #4: Simulation study comparing 6-region vs 9-region performance, "areas-as-fleets" approach
- Decision needed: Move to 6-region or maintain 9-region complexity?
:::

## Issue #2: Spatial Structure {data-background-image="static/spc-slide-sidebar.png" data-background-size="5% 100%" data-background-position="left"}

::: {style="margin-left: 1.5%; margin-right: 1.5%; font-size: 0.6em; line-height: 1.3;"}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="52%"}
### 9-Region Problems

- 41 fisheries, 3,067 parameters, ~24-hour runtime
- Persistent convergence issues (Hessian, correlations)
- Jittering sensitivity
- Complex for stable estimation

### Evidence Supporting 6-Region

**Biological data** [@hamer2023spatial]:
- Low tropical ↔ temperate movement
- High mixing within tropical/temperate zones
- Size composition clustering supports simpler structure

**Model performance**:
- 6-region used 2005-2011 successfully
- Faster runtime, fewer parameters
- Better convergence stability

### SC19-#4

Simulation study: 6-region vs 9-region performance; "areas-as-fleets" approach
:::

::: {.column width="48%"}
![Proposed 6-region [@hamer2023spatial]](figures/prepaw/spatial-fig-004.png){width=100%}

:::
:::

:::

::: {.notes}
- 2024 catch spike: Large increase from reclassifying small to large handline gear
- Major uncertainty in historical allocation between BET and YFT
- Data quality issues: BET/YFT difficult to distinguish, no clear species criteria
- Port sampling only (<5%), no observers, no logbooks, catches aggregated evenly across time/space
- Impact: Major tropical biomass uncertainty, size composition conflicts with other data sources
- SC19 recommendation #11: Comprehensive review of Region 7 fisheries and size composition representativeness
- Decision needed: Accept 2024 spike? Smooth transition? Historical consistency?
:::

## Issue #4: Tag Mixing Assumptions {data-background-image="static/spc-slide-sidebar.png" data-background-size="5% 100%" data-background-position="left"}

::: {style="margin-left: 1.5%; margin-right: 1.5%; font-size: 0.6em; line-height: 1.3;"}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="52%"}
### Problem

- Unknown mixing period (current: 2Q, no validation)
- Varies by location, FAD vs free school, size, season

### Impact

- **Most influential grid axis** in 2023
- Affects biomass scale, F-at-age patterns
- Confounded with tag-reporting rates

### Data: ~67K BET Tagged

RTTP (1989-92): 8.6K; PTTP (2006-20): 59K; JPTP (2000-20): added in 2020

### SC19-#14

Develop diagnostics; test 1Q/2Q/3Q; quantify uncertainty [@peatman2023tagger]
:::

::: {.column width="48%"}
![Tag programs [@day2023bet]](figures/prepaw/bet2023-fig-002.png){width=100%}
:::
:::

:::

::: {.notes}
- 2023 assessment used fixed weights throughout - no iterative reweighting
- Data conflicts: **Weight composition vs length/tagging** pull opposite directions [@day2023bet]
- "Inversion": Weight data suggests lower biomass, length/tagging suggests higher biomass
- Causes: Unrepresentative sampling, coverage gaps, selectivity/growth misspecification
- Impact: Biomass scale and reference point uncertainty
- SC19 recommendations #11, #12: Review representativeness, investigate inversion phenomenon
- Need: Implement iterative reweighting methods (Francis, Dirichlet-multinomial) for 2026
:::

## Issue #5: Size Composition Weighting {data-background-image="static/spc-slide-sidebar.png" data-background-size="5% 100%" data-background-position="left"}

::: {style="margin-left: 1.5%; margin-right: 1.5%; font-size: 0.6em; line-height: 1.3;"}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="52%"}
### Problem

**No iterative reweighting in 2023**:
- Fixed weights throughout
- No adjustment for data conflicts

### Data Conflicts

- **Weight comp vs length/tagging** pull opposite directions [@day2023bet]
- **"Inversion"**: Weight → lower biomass; length/tags → higher biomass

### Causes

- Unrepresentative sampling, coverage gaps
- Selectivity/growth misspecification

### Impact

- Biomass scale and reference point uncertainty

### SC19-#11, #12

Review representativeness; investigate inversion
:::

::: {.column width="48%"}
![Likelihood profile [@day2023bet]](figures/prepaw/bet2023-fig-013.png){width=100%}
:::
:::

:::

::: {.notes}
- Tropical regions (3, 4, 7, 8): Unfished SSB increases over time - biologically implausible
- Causes: Regional recruitment allocation patterns, movement parameter specifications, initial population distribution assumptions
- Impact: Questions model biological realism, virgin biomass reference point uncertainty, regional depletion estimates unreliable
- SC19 recommendation #5: Investigate model specifications causing this trend
- Need: Diagnose root cause and implement corrections for 2026
:::

## Issue #7: Model Convergence {data-background-image="static/spc-slide-sidebar.png" data-background-size="5% 100%" data-background-position="left"}

::: {style="margin-left: 1.5%; margin-right: 1.5%; font-size: 0.62em; line-height: 1.3;"}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="48%"}
### Problem & Results

**Sensitivity to initial conditions** — Models achieve suboptimal local minima

**Diagnostic model**:
- Primary jittering (60x): Improvements of **tens to hundreds** of likelihood units
- Stock status shifts: **5%+ in SB/SB~F=0~**

**Grid models**:
- Before: 46/54 with PDH → After: **48/54 with PDH**
- **Every model improved** through jittering

**SC19-#9, #13**: Identify correlated/sensitive parameters; strategies to decrease starting value sensitivity
:::

::: {.column width="52%"}
### Key Findings [@day2023bet]

::: {style="background-color: #fff5f5; padding: 0.7em; border-left: 4px solid #d32f2f; margin-bottom: 0.8em;"}
> "**Model convergence is a significant issue** for these complex models... **jittering is an important process** to refine and improve the best solution."
:::

::: {style="background-color: #fff5f5; padding: 0.7em; border-left: 4px solid #d32f2f; margin-bottom: 0.8em;"}
> "Jittered solutions achieved **improved objective function values** and **notable changes to derived management quantities**. This was cause for **considerable concern**."
:::

::: {style="background-color: #fff5f5; padding: 0.7em; border-left: 4px solid #d32f2f;"}
> "**Every grid model** improved through jittering — **none was at a global minimum**, even those 46 with positive definite Hessians."
:::
:::
:::

:::

::: {.notes}
- Biggest technical challenge: Sensitivity to initial conditions, models achieve suboptimal local minima
- Diagnostic model primary jittering (60 runs): Improvements of tens to hundreds of likelihood units
- Stock status shifts 5%+ in SB/SBF=0 depending on starting values
- Grid models: Before 46/54 with PDH → After 48/54 with PDH, but EVERY model improved through jittering
- Critical finding: "None was at a global minimum, even those 46 with positive definite Hessians"
- Authors' assessment: "Considerable concern" - jittering "important process" to refine solutions
- SC19 recommendations #9, #13: Identify correlated/sensitive parameters, decrease starting value sensitivity
- Top priority for 2026: Improve convergence stability to ensure reliable management advice
:::

## Foundation: 2023 Model {data-background-image="static/spc-slide-sidebar.png" data-background-size="5% 100%" data-background-position="left"}

- 2026 proposed sensitivities: Spatial structure (6R vs 9R per SC19 #4 simulation study), tag mixing period (add 3Q, Piner plot validation per SC19 #14), structural (natural mortality scaling, selectivity patterns), data treatment (Indonesia catch revision, CPUE effort creep, size comp weighting schemes)
- Results presentation: Median stock status, 80% credible intervals, key biological reference points, Kobe plots by scenario
- Grid design balances computational feasibility with uncertainty characterization
:::

- 1 quarter

**3. Size composition weighting** [@peatman2023size]:
- 10 (high weight)
- 20 (base)
- 40 (low weight)

**4. Age composition weighting** [@day2023bet]:
- 0.50 (low weight)
- 0.75 (base)
- 1.00 (high weight)

- 6-region vs 9-region

**Tag mixing period** (**SC19-#14**):
- 3 quarters (extended)
- Piner plot validation

**Structural**:
- Natural mortality scaling
- Selectivity patterns

**Data treatment**:
- Indonesia catch revision
- CPUE effort creep
- Size comp weighting schemes

::: {.notes}
- Convergence strategy (SC19 #9, #13): Profile correlated parameters, test parameter fixing, reduce dimensionality, multiple starting values (jittering), phased estimation, Hessian diagnostics, alternative optimization algorithms
- Simplification options: Consider 6R vs 9R spatial structure, fishery aggregations, selectivity parameterization, movement parameters
- Enhanced diagnostics: Retrospective analysis (peel test, Mohns rho), tag diagnostics (SC19 #14 - likelihood profiles, tagger effects, mixing period validation), residual analysis (size comp/CPUE/tag recovery fits, systematic patterns)
- Quality control: Extensive testing (gradient checks, likelihood profiles, parameter correlations, sensitivity to data subsets)
- Goal: Achieve stable, converged models with positive definite Hessians for reliable management advice
:::

## Key Questions {data-background-image="static/spc-slide_sidebar.png" data-background-size="5% 100%" data-background-position="left"}

::: {style="margin-left: 1.5%; margin-right: 1.5%; font-size: 0.6em; line-height: 1.3;"}

::: {.columns}

### Decisions Needed

**1. Spatial** **SC19-#4**
  - 9R vs 6R?
  - Both in grid?

**2. Tag mixing** **SC19-#14**
  - Test 1Q, 2Q, 3Q?
  - All in grid or select one?

**3. Growth** **SC19-#7**
  - Internal estimation?
  - Or external priors?
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Guidance Needed

**4. Indonesia catch**
  - Accept 2024 spike?
  - Smooth transition?
  - Maintain historical?

**5. Analysis priorities**
  - CPUE effort creep? **SC19-#3**
  - Yield-per-recruit? **SC19-#6**

::: {.notes}
- Decision #1 (Spatial, SC19 #4): Move to 6 regions or maintain 9? Run both in grid or select one?
- Decision #2 (Tag mixing, SC19 #14): Test 1Q, 2Q, 3Q periods? Include all in grid or select best based on diagnostics?
- Decision #3 (Growth, SC19 #7): Continue internal estimation or use external priors for stability?
- Decision #4 (Indonesia catch): Accept 2024 spike as-is? Smooth transition? Maintain historical allocation?
- Decision #5 (Priorities): Focus limited time on CPUE effort creep (SC19 #3) or yield-per-recruit (SC19 #6)? Cannot adequately address all recommendations.
- Guidance determines 8-month work plan to SC20
- Need clear priorities to deliver robust assessment on schedule
